result.execSummary:
The defendant Matthew Allen Scherper was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Burglary-Building or Dwelling, a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.10(1m)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: Fines, costs, and restitution are due during term of supervision.  Dept of Corrections to collect from defendant's wages and from other monies held in the defendant's inmate account, an amount or a percentage which the department determines is reasonable.  If defendant is released with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment enforceable by all creditors' remedies shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.

Not to possess or consume controlled substances or prescription medication w/out a valid prescription. 

Absolute sobriety.  No possession/consumption of any intoxicants. 

Defendant to undergo any mental health treatment and follow up determined appropriate by supervising agent.

Defendant to continue taking prescribed medications.

Defendant to submit a DNA sample.

records.addlTxt: 10:36 AM Defendant Matthew A Scherper appeared by video, in custody.  Attorney Martin Russell Tanz in court for Matthew A Scherper.  Prosecuting attorney Benjamin Lindsay in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant wishes to proceed to sentencing via video.  Court goes off the record to allow defendant to be brought into court.  Court back on the record at 11:41 am with same appearances, defendant now in court:  Court examines Defendant as to submitted plea questionnaire.  Defendant enters guilty plea as to count 1.  Court accepts the plea, finding it to be free and voluntary, and finds the Defendant guilty as to their plea.  State as to sentencing.  Statements by Defendant's Mother.  Counsel as to sentencing.  Statements by Defendant.  Court renders judgment.

Plea/sentencing hearing on September 29, 2022 at 10:00 am.
